title: 109_hr5321
content: The Act titled "Access to Better Choice in Dialysis Act of 2006" allows for a Medicare pilot project for more frequent hemodialysis treatment. The "Access to Better Choice in Dialysis Act of 2006" mandates a 5-year pilot project to assess the impact of increasing payment for hemodialysis treatment beyond 3 times per week. Payment amounts for additional sessions are specified as percentages of the full composite rate. The pilot program for hemodialysis treatment includes payment amounts for additional sessions based on percentages of the full composite rate, with funding limitations set for each year of operation. The pilot program for hemodialysis treatment includes funding limitations set for each year of operation, with data collection to measure the impact of higher frequency treatments on health status and healthcare expenditures. Funding from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund will be available in advance to meet obligations arising from the program. The pilot program for hemodialysis treatment includes funding limitations for healthcare services like drugs and hospitalizations, as well as monitoring patients' working status for impact on Social Security, tax payments, and Medicare coverage. The Secretary will submit periodic reports to Congress on the program. The Medicare Payment Advisory Commission will evaluate the Secretary's findings on the clinical and financial impact of more frequent hemodialysis treatment and submit a report to Congress on the desirability of expanded Medicare payment for such treatment. The term "full composite rate" refers to the rate determined under the Social Security Act. The Social Security Act defines "hemodialysis treatment" as therapy requiring blood access, excluding emergency or acute treatment. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
